job_title: International Logistics Coordinator in Changi Village,
pros: Good welfare and nice colleagues
cons: Long hours. No work life

pros: The mission to find a cure.
cons: Observing instances of favoritism that have negatively impacted morale and employee motivation. It is disheartening to witness situations where personal connections seem to hold more weight than merit or performance. Secondly, poor leadership that has resulted in a toxic work environment. The lack of effective communication, accountability, and guidance from certain leaders has created an atmosphere of uncertainty and frustration. This has hindered our collective ability to perform optimally and contribute to the organization's success. Furthermore, I have experienced a lack of support from the Human Resources department when attempting to address workplace concerns. It is crucial for HR to provide a safe and supportive environment for employees to voice their concerns without fear of reprisal. Unfortunately, my attempts to seek assistance and resolution have been met with indifference, which only perpetuates the existing problems. Also, I have noticed instances of retaliation against employees who have raised valid concerns or acted as whistleblowers. This discourages open dialogue, hampers trust, and perpetuates a culture of silence. A system that supports and protects employees who come forward with genuine concerns is essential to promoting a healthy and transparent work environment. Lastly, I am disappointed by the lack of clear paths for professional advancement within the organization. It often appears that opportunities for growth and development are limited to those who maintain close relationships with management, rather than being based on merit and potential. This creates a sense of frustration and hampers the motivation of ambitious employees who strive to contribute more to the organization.

pros: I loved working with the breast cancer community. Great benefits package, lots of time off and flexibility in schedule
cons: After a career in nonprofit leadership and major gifts, I wasn’t interested in P2P. They are understaffed and do not support employees with HR issues. Most departments have no room for advancement, just lateral moves that can result in lower salary or job level (like director to manager) Anyone with a major gift background will probably be frustrated

pros: Work/life balance; rated Top 23 businesses for best remote workplace; awesome co-workers

Most team leaders are open to new ideas and experimenting. CEO is a breath of fresh air, for an executive, open minded and respectful of others. Culture is fun, remote and flexible.
cons: Benefits and paid leave could be better but it’s a non profit! Some sensitivities still lingering from old issues which can get in the way of work.

review_title: Best Organization For Which I Have Ever Worked
pros: Strategic, organized, planned and proactive - and we stick to our strategies. If we shift, we shift our strategies. Leadership is focused and doesn't "chase shiny objects". Everyone is rowing in the same direction. Strict focus on diversity and inclusion.
cons: After 40 years, Komen is experiencing a new infancy after restructuring and evolving but it only presents new(er) challenges vs. detracting from the mission or quality of achievements. There are still some 'old school' employees that can cause progress to drag with woes of how it used to be.

review_title: Great mission and opportunities to build the future
pros: There is a LOT going on at Komen and lots of professional opportunities. The mission is three-fold: research, public health and public policy - this is not a one trick pony organization. Komen is moving toward providing services directly to patients rather than through grantmaking, which is a huge change to the business model, and offers opportunities for staff to actually build this new program and craft the future of the organization. Many team members have a personal connection to the cause, which helps keep mission front and center. It's gratifying to see firsthand how the work helps patients first, but also pushes science forward. Lots of flexibility - the entire organization is now work-from-home and accommodates all of the challenges we have with COVID-19, like dealing with kids and spouses at home and working among some chaos. The benefits are awesome, and include really, really good health insurance (so important right now).
cons: It can be a very fast pace environment, and working from home is not for everyone. There are no plans to go back to an office and many of the in-person events can't happen, so that community feeling is tough right now. Like everyone else, I'm all Zoom-ed out.

pros:
Flexible hours
Good management
Happy workforce
Good working hours around kids
cons: Nothing that I can think of

pros: Great place to work in public health
cons: Can’t think of anything bad to say

pros: Remote positions helping people with breast cancer
cons: Recently merged into new organization and still trying to merge/create culture.

pros: Excellent culture, good managers - fully remote
cons: Still growing from affiliate consolidation.

review_title: Good Mission but Employees Overworked and Under-appreciated
pros: Mission helps those in need. Takes a well rounded approach (patient navigation, treatment assistance, public policy, research, etc) to helping those diagnosed with breast cancer. Employs so many individuals that truly care about the mission (many of whom are personally impacted by breast cancer). Because they are always short-staffed, you will expand your skillset working on projects way outside your expertise (but this type of working environment isn’t sustainable long term). HR seems to genuinely want to improve work culture.
cons: Employees are overworked, overwhelmed, and working in high stress conditions with a shortage of appreciation - this leads to burnout & high turnover.  Promotions are limited. When someone leaves, their work just gets piled on to remaining team members, thus increasing workloads and responsibility but with no change in title or pay. Yet, ‘green’ outsiders are hired on with higher titles and pay than the dedicated and experienced employees who contribute much more. Expect to be available to work on weekends, holidays and while on PTO. As a non-profit, annual budgets are tumultuous so expect to see cycles of mass lay-offs followed by mass hiring (and so on).

pros: Genuinely contributing to positive change
cons: In-person trainings felt like a networking marketing scheme

job_title: Manager, Patient Navigation in Houston, TX
pros: Work life balance, flexibility, work from home and good work culture. HR was phenomenal during my interviewing process and during my onboarding as well.
cons: No bonuses and I wish the health, vision and dental premiums were cheaper but they are still at a reasonable price.

pros: The staff at Susan G Komen are high caliber and many have a personal attachment to the cause. There are a lot of exciting changes that keep the work interesting.

pros: I have only been with Komen for one month but wanted to give feedback on the virtual interview and onboarding process. It was quick (4 weeks!) smooth, and positive! I had two interviews and then a discussion with the HR Manager. They turned the offer and letter around quickly! There have been several trainings and welcome calls/meetings that have made me feel like a part of a great team - even from a distance. I was sent a Komen swag bag full of Komen-branded things that I will and a beautiful welcome card that made my day! I have been very impressed and pleased with the welcome , the process, and the Komen team thus far.
cons: I have not identified any cons as of yet!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: The people who volunteer and genuinely support the mission, and the chance to interact with breast cancer survivors and know that you are helping them.
cons: No structure internally with staff.  No training.  Everything is last minute.  No support.  No internal staff meetings at all.  No one knows what's going on unless they decide to make you privy.  Very clique-y.  No employee reviews or feedback. The local affiliate has been doing the Race for so long, they are hesitant or closed off to new ideas or suggestions, but again, no system to keep you informed.  You have to create your own system.  Leadership is very poor, and there is no local HR to air grievances.  There is a high turnover rate for a reason.

pros: Great working environment to work with
cons: Just okay. Poor management .they dont help

review_title: One of the best organizations to work for which has become apparent during the current COVID-19 business environment.
pros: Very strong leadership and vision during a period of uncertainty in the nonprofit community with a laser focus on how to effect change to reduce its aggressive goal (breast cancer deaths). Recent actions have streamlined organization so it better can respond and pivot to changes in the business environment. Executive leadership is transparent about efforts and actions to position the nonprofit so it can adapt to current and future changing business environments. Weekly communications from a very authentic CEO, staff employees are highly skilled, who have strong work ethics, and committed to the vision and goal. New initiatives are in process and it is clear recent actions have had a lot of thought and intentionality.
cons: The changing business environment (COVID-19) precludes a comment in this area. Through necessity, the norms of the past are not the norms of the present or future. The organization is dealing with issues head on, and while it does create uncertainty with each change, it is not necessarily bad.

pros: Their mission is important and there are many well-meaning people. The affiliate staff and volunteers are passionate about the cause. The pay is competitive with other area nonprofits and the benefits are good.
cons: Where should I begin? This place is a mess! Employee moral was already low, but after the Planned Parenthood debacle and subsequent drop in donations, it is horrible. The senior staff are self-centered and their attempts to develop and support employees comes across as contrived and superficial. The board provides no real leadership and defers entirely to the founder and CEO. It is a prime example of Founder's Syndrome. There is an unhealthy tension (to put it mildly) between the affiliates and the national office that makes it hard to get things done. The good staff have departed or are looking to leave, and the ones who remain are too incompetent to find another job. Don't be fooled by talk of "work-life balance." How can an organization be balanced when its senior staff don't know the meaning of the word?

pros:
Corporate HQ  employees qualify for flex time. You can either work 7.5 hours a day and work from home 1 day a week or work a compressed schedule and get a day off every other week.  Benefits are solid. 21 days PTO to start which I feel is very generous. 
Overall my coworkers have a lot of heart, and I feel like the vast majority of the people who work here are here for the right reasons.
It's eye opening how much Komen is doing behind the scenes, and I feel proud to be part of it.
cons: I think a lot of change has happened in a very short period of time. A lot of the change was necessary in order to make us more efficient, but I feel like some of it could have been handled more delicately. Overall I think things are moving in the right direction in order to do right by the communities we serve.

pros: People who are unpaid interns for Komen should NOT be reviewing Komen as a work place. They are VOLUNTEERS and can pretty much come and go as they please without consequences. It makes me laugh to see how they all write that they have nothing bad to say about the place. Of course they don't. Please refine your system, Glassdoor. These reviews are largely meaningless.
cons: If you do not make yourself constantly available, even at nights and on weekends, or to travel at the drop of a hat, be prepared to be looked at as a non-starter and a person who is not a team player. I knew several people at management level who made a habit of staying late EVERY NIGHT, by two or three hours. But their 'work' consisted of writing and answering personal e-mails, posting selfies on FB, or all sorts of other personal stuff. But they came out looking like heroes to the organization, because they 'worked late' all the time. So aggravating.

review_title: A great organization with hit-or-miss affiliates.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bonita Springs, FL
pros: Great mission, strong admin and marketing support from corporate.  Thoroughly enjoyed my time working with some other affiliates, and everyone from corporate.
cons: Some affiliates might as well not be part of Komen.  Thoroughly disliked my time working for Komen SWFL.  Director and Board President spoke out of both sides of their mouth.  Would have been proud of my job at other affiliates, but embarrassed by the hypocrisy, elitism, and and vitriol at this affiliate.  Constant turnover for a tiny office.  No health benefits of any kind, even for employees at high risk and with family history of breast cancer.  Retaliation for HR complaints.

pros:
Strong MISSION focus. All activities are to be connected (directly or indirectly) to each individual Affiliate's Mission Action Plan... which is based on each Affiliate's most recent Community Profile (an exhaustive, in-depth look at breast health needs, available resources, etc. within each Affiliate's footprint). 

Excellent organizational atmosphere/culture. Pro-active. Solution-oriented. Team-focus. 

Overall, solid reciprocal communication pathways across the network. Though not always immediately, I was never not able to connect with the individual(s) I needed to resolve an issue or talk through a concern.
cons:
Lots of network-wide changes currently underway. Necessary changes, but makes for a challenging, often uncertain environment. The organization as a whole will be much better equipped to continue fulfilling it's mission once the dust settles. Made for exciting times. I have no regrets.

With an organization of this size, public relations challenges are to be expected. Be ready with knowledgeable, respectful responses. 

Limited benefits (i.e. health insurance, etc.) at the Affiliate level (varies greatly from Affiliate to Affiliate).

review_title: Great Place to work and make a difference!
job_title: Prefer Not To Say in Dallas, TX
pros: Working for a non-profit who is focused on saving lives and making a difference to those living with breast cancer is rewarding.  It's hard work but worth every minute! The organization is changing and evolving under Paula Schneider and starting to really move forward.  The benefits and PTO is great.  The pay is competitive.  The biggest challenge is getting the word out on all of the great things being done on a daily basis!
cons: The HQ (main entity) is small ~220 employees.  The good news is it allows for opportunity for learning new skills as everyone has to roll up their sleeves but there aren't a lot of layers for promotion opportunities.  So, there are some internal promotion opportunities but sometimes people need to leave to open up promotion opportunity.

pros: Lots of educational opportunities to learn about breast cancer; The operations staff doing the actual work are passionate about the cause; HR was always an organization that pushed to improve things for employees.
cons:
Management, management, management. From the top down, it's some of the worst I've seen. The only solutions I saw implemented in an attempt to address their financial demise were focused on layoff's and cutbacks. There was no real innovation by senior leadership to change the company's course. And when they failed, they bailed after collecting their paycheck for 1-2 years. 

IT management was horrendous. They would take away benefits from employees for using sick time. They put into place rules for communication that required the employee to respond within 15 minutes or else their flex time (work from home) benefit would be taken away.  Some IT managers were reported to HR for this behavior.

pros: Working with the Susan G. Komen team was a pleasure - great atmosphere, great employees, lots of fun and very satisfying to do such great work.
cons: If you accept an internship, be prepared for a lot of work and ZERO pay.  Literally, zero.  They usually have enough money to pay for one intern, but that's it.  It's pretty unfair that the paid intern is working just as hard and as many long hours as the rest of the interns but they are the only one getting paid.

pros: It's a good cause and the company invests donor dollars wisely. They have made amazing progress in the breast cancer fight.
cons: Certain management is disrespectful and seems to enjoy watching their employees scramble to try to meet their unrealistic expectations. The staff is mostly talented and intelligent, but it's a near constant beatdown regardless, particularly if you're in a revenue generating department. There is minimal regard for work/life balance, and everything is treated as an emergency. You will work weekends and see your VP checking in at her workout class while you're working on the "urgent" task she gave you the day before.

review_title: Still a mission worth helping women
pros: A dedicated loyal network of volunteers, survivors & staff who are focused on the mission of ending breast cancer forever.
cons: The Planned Parenthood issue drained the spirit  of the organization,as the daily fight took away valuable resources from the mission, and impacted donor relationships as well as losing key talent. With new CEO in place, perhaps they can get back on track and  back to helping saving women around the world.

review_title: RUN!!!! Do NOT work here…I repeat, do NOT work here!
pros: Work/life balance is ok.  However, people don't come into the office because of the environment, so work should be a little more existent.
cons:
Leadership at the local Chicago affiliate is atrocious.  The board doesn't get their responsibility and the CEO is dreadful.  SGK has not overcome the Planned Parenthood debacle and this organization more than likely won't be around for the long haul (and shouldn't be).  The National office provides no support and the communication between local and national offices is nonexistent.  There are so many great breast cancer organizations truly making an impact in breast cancer - support them - American Cancer Society, Bright Pink, Lynn Sage.  
And don't expect good benefits.  You'll need to figure out another avenue for health, retirement, and basic insurance.

pros: The group I worked for in the IT Department was great. They take care of their employees fairly. You will be paid well per standards, and pay a decent bonus whenever the company does well. There is no stress since the managers in this department are organized and tend to make their employees keep things organized. Terrific work-life balance, second to none I have seen. Will work out good for people with kids, especially moms.
cons: Not sure about the growth of the company. If you are very ambitious, you might want to look elsewhere.

pros:
- Flexible Hours and willingness to work with my schedule
- Paid internship that was consistently renewed and had opportunity to advance
- Great Supervisors who looked out for me and helped me grow professionally
cons:
- Organization was floundering some, so it was not always the most cheerful 
- Upper management listened to department's request for a new part time employee... But then laid off another employee to make up for the additional cost

pros: The overall concept of helping people is good. And the more you are not at headquarters, the more you will experience this.
cons: Upper management is harsh and creates  a toxic environment in which to work. There is very little respect or  encouragement for original ideas. There  ia a lot of micromanagement and negative chatter throughout the office. Hardly any chance for advancement. Very little chance for professional development. Also, nearly everything is presented like an emergency. There is no respect for work-life balance because even though they failed to inform you of a project that needed to be done in a timely manner, you are expected to complete it immediately regardless of anything else going on either as part of your job or part of your life.

pros: SGK did phenomenal work to bring awareness to breast cancer.  Local affiliates carried out the mission and made incredible in-roads and saved many lives in local communitirs.
cons: Absolutely poor management at every level at HQ. The minimum fundraising requirement of ONE MILLION DOLLARS at the local level has resulted in the loss off more than half of local affiliates and left gaps all over the nation. Entire states have closed, some following basically forced mergers. Too little. Too late. So many committed people who worked for Komen because they believed in the mission have lost their jobs.  Wish I had not loved the mission and the people so much and had moved on before wasting so many years of my life, only to realize nobody cared.

review_title: Run, do not walk away from here!
pros: At this point, there’s not much to say.  Most of the people are well meaning and work hard.
cons: The senior leadership is clueless on how to manage the reorganization and none of them have the experience in managing an organization like the one they’re trying to become.  Decisions are being made too quickly with too many people who don’t understand the field, the constituents or the skills needed to keep the organization going.  You couldn’t pay me a million dollars to work here again.  It’s toxic and they are so concerned about saving themselves they are doing everything people have always accused them of.

pros: Most of the employees are supportive, kind, and good at their job. Pay and benefits are good. Mission is good. HR provides good team building and career development events for staff.
cons: If upper management are criticized for any decisions that they've made, they will make employees on the lowers tiers their scapegoats. If you aren't telepathic, you will struggle. Policies and procedures are changed on a whim with no announcement, and you will get criticized for not knowing of the change. Work/life balance is bad. Employee appreciation is bad.

pros: Mission, dedicated employees, volunteers and donors, HR engagement team for healthy lifestyle, great benefits, salary aligned with other same size non-profits,
cons: Executive leadership changes too frequently with lay offs every 18-24 months.  Work/life balance is not realistic, especially if you are supervisory or above.  No budget for personal or professional development.

pros: altruism,  great cause, some great people
cons: Komen's founder destroyed the organization in 2012. It hasn't recovered since and never will. Currently, the place is in total disarray. It's a true dog eat dog environment as everybody desperately tries to keep the place afloat. Management is atrocious - they can barely get along with each other much less their own teams. The incessantly poor decisions they make leave everyone scratching their heads wondering then the next layoff will occur. It's a revolving door of incompetence at the top levels. The ship has already sunk. It's only a matter of time before Komen announces they're closing their doors. Stay away. If Breast Cancer is your cause, go to BCRF.

pros: Dedicated staff all aligned with the singular mission to find a cure for breast cancer. Very organized staffing break down with clear roles assigned and I knew who to turn to for help on different projects. I enjoyed the variety of programs I got to work on. Great benefits!
cons: Went through some tough times around the Planned Parenthood decision and changes in CEO and lots of turnover around that time made things difficult

review_title: Run don't walk away from Komen
pros: There are some dedicated people in place, ones that are passionate about the mission
cons: Honestly, everything else. They're pay isn't competitive, their review process is horrible. Most importantly they have the wrong senior leadership staff in place. Unfortunately in those positions it is a constant revolving door and as soon as a new senior leader is hired they want to change things to do it "their way". Every two - three years there is an overhaul which makes it hard to be successful. I don't see them changing their ways, every talented person I've met has left because of the culture.

pros: Emotional fulfilling job, training available at corporate HQ in TX, fun rewarding career
cons: board egos, corporate doesn't care about the local level if you are profitable. If you're not profitable they pay attention to the board downfalls. Board has to much control over the position, the board requires you to have experience, yet board members are not required to have experience. Board members look for benefits to help their companies be profitable regardless that its unethical. 5 Executive directors in 5 years, ugh hello corporate!

pros: The time off plans are very generous, the ability to balance work/life with their flex schedule makes it worth while.  I have enjoyed the various levels of support we have in our office.  The invaluable mission I am now apart of is priceless!
cons: Update some of the older paper trail processes as permitted, sounds like it's on everyone's radar to do so.

review_title: Incompetent, power hungry and self-congratulatory - afraid of change, backwards and behind the times
pros: Great benefits package, 9-5 (or less) if you're not a Director, everyone is very nice and never argues
cons: Senior leadership is incompetent, no one else would hire them; no opportunity for growth or cross-training; they claim to be mission focused but are really focused on empire building to the exclusion of intelligent business decisions or good management; more concerned with appearances and public image; no work/life balance if you are Director or above; no strategic planning or business sense

pros: In my experience working at Susan G. Komen i have had Amazing colleagues and have seen first hand the importance of the mission.
cons: Susan G. Komen faces struggles just as any other NPO. Staff turnover, small staff sizes at each office so employees tend to where multiple hats from time to time. Sucess is dependant on strong donor databases as well as volunteer / intern programs.

pros: Helping a good cause / being in the nonprofit sector (although after working here, I firmly believe there are better ways to truly impact this cause)
cons: Disorganized from the ground up, inefficient in how headquarters works with local affiliates, poor culture, limited resources, high rate of turnover, high overhead - local chapters are working hard just to keep their doors open (and some aren't even able to do that)

review_title: NonProfit that benefits community; doesn't invest in staff
pros: Large non-profit that provides much needed services to large service area. Has a great relationship with its volunteers. Staff is great to work with as a team. Very good health care benefits package.
cons: No work/life balance. Micromanagement. No professional development. No investment in employees. Vacation days have decreased.

pros: The proud feeling to work there, the people that I worked with, the atmosphere that I worked in and overall just the experience
cons: Pay isn't the best, but what do you expect its a non profit job, but it is rewarding, so it makes up for it/

pros: Rewarding. Money that is raised helps local breast cancer programs and survivors. Large group of dedicated volunteers to help execute events.
cons: Expected to do many tasks, many hours per week with little pay or benefits. Administration has difficulty allowing autonomy for employees.

pros: Flexible hours, great medical plan and parking is free when available
cons: Negative attitude throughout organization.  Pay was lower than competitors and advancement was based on fear of losing employees not merit.  They do not seem to care about what they exist to eliminate and there are many unethical things happening all the time.  If you like a kindergarten playground you will enjoy working here

pros: Great mission and name recognition.  Good central auditing of financial operations.
cons: Poor central management; no board limits; senior management at national level has been in place for too long; too political.

pros: Nice people, mission-focused, management really makes an effort to involve everything in company culture.
cons: Everything is last minute and there's no real effort to try to manage projects efficiently.    Very little opportunity for upward movement and very low salaries.  Training is on-the-job, figure it out as you go whereas sometimes attending a course could have led to greater improvements at a quicker pace.

job_title: Office Aid, Internship in Lexington, KY
pros: Great experience for an even greater cause. Quality organization and people to work with. If unavailable to work next year, will definitely volunteer my available time.
cons: Due to the fact the Lexington Affiliate is a up and coming sector of the Komen for the Cure foundation, the positions are limited and seasonal.  Wish there was more too do for the organization year round.

pros: Lots of perks and freebies. Great benefits.
cons: Where do I start.....let's just say that i wanted to love working here because of Komen's mission and cause. However, in my department, there is zero to no chance of making it up the ladder. There is a "good 'ole boys" network where friends of upper management (with no experience) are hired before anybody else is even considered! Long list of negatives that I'd rather not revisit.

review_title: SGK is a lot of work for a little money,but you have the gratification of knowing that what you do benefits others.
pros: Working with amazing volunteers was very gratifying as was knowing our work was making a real difference in peoples lives.
cons: Low Pay compared to the amount of work required and the management t was not honest or ethical.

pros: Great mission; Majority of personalities are not "difficult," easy-going environment. newly renovated office space; HQ offices conveniently located within Dallas; accepts remote employees for some positions.
cons: Senior leadership has led the company in a downward trend for the last six years, with revenues continuing to decline. Marketing officers are in and out, making the company's ability to focus on a long-term plan difficult, and it's been failing to do so for many years. The company recently had layoffs, but they only laid off good employees and no management positions despite management's lack of results. Management is ineffective, as demonstrated by the continually declining revenues and the lack of good morale among many departments. No CEO is currently in place as the board ousted the last CEO after waiting three years with no results.  Not only does the company continue to maintain a leadership team that is ineffective, but it's "fat" with leadership -- too many director's and manager's positions who lead merely between 2-5 employees at the most. This is an enormous waste of donor dollars. The company has been dipping into its reserves for the last several years to attempt to stay afloat. The company also offers flex time (which is a good thing), but management's insecurity causes the full flex benefit to be denied to its employees because it’s a benefit offered "according to each department’s discretion," so essentially the company "sells" a particular flex benefit package to new hires yet managers take it away because they are given the ability to do so, which is misleading, and this negatively impacts morale. Bonuses disappeared long ago and show no sign of returning.

pros:
Staff is very dedicated to mission.  Small staff and work very well with each other.
Generous paid vacation, personal leave, and sick leave.  Very understanding and willing to work with employee for personal time/hours.Open to new ideas.
cons:
Two months of extremely busy work schedules with signature event in summer. Not a set policy for overtime and compensation of time. 
Not alot of chance for advancement.

review_title: A Fantastic Organization to Learn From
pros: It's a small group, so you get to know each other really well. If you ever have a question, everyone is willing to help. They take great care of the community. I learned so much from working there.
cons: Sometimes the work load is heavy, but it's only because they're trying to do so much with such a small staff.

pros: It was nice to be working for such a good cause, and was altogether a very pleasant daily office atmosphere.
cons: Working for a nonprofit means often a smaller payscale, and working environment can be slightly chaotic around the time of big events.

review_title: Struggling to keep the ship afloat
pros: Work with purpose.  Opportunity to see good results from hard work.
cons: Too little support for affiliates. Unrealistic work load and unrealistic demands without enough training, support, etc.

review_title: HQ may operate on a professional level, but the Affiliates are still "Grassroots"
pros: Well known non-profit, good cause
cons: Inexperienced managers with poor communication skills and inability to direct their staff. When staff tries to accomplish their goals, management continually plays to volunteers doing work to smooth their egos instead of relying on the talent of the staff that they *pay*.

pros: You get to work with a really passionate group of women. It's amazing what they can accomplish even though there are so few of them.
cons: The different affiliates of the organization seem to have some issues of getting things done when everything has to be run by the main office.

job_title: Executive Director in New York, NY
pros: Amazing professional development in support of the brand. The regular routines of professional development training for executives is a real plus!
cons: Mixed messages about ensuring the community is engaged. There is a need for more effective end to end community impact planning and evaluation.

pros: Working on a good cause; public health approach to education/awareness is getting better and more recognition versus just handing out pink pins and sweaters
cons: Affiliates are to be directed by National; no room for creative programming

review_title: A very pleasant atmosphere to work in.
pros: The people at Susan G. Komen are wonderful! Every department is great! There are always learning opportunities and chances to grow within the company.
cons: It is a small company so there are not too many job openings and getting promoted can be difficult.

review_title: Great learning experience for an intern
job_title: Social Media/Marketing Intern in Austin, TX
pros: Great work environment and great management. The staff is willing to help you with any questions you have. It's a great place to intern to gain real world experience in a nonprofit.
cons: Unpaid internships. Other than that, no other cons.

pros: Employees are driven! Employees really are influential and strive to help as much as possible! Work environment is awesome and friendly!
cons: Small offices at local organizations. Work office doesn't apply to everyone, but if your a type of person who likes quiet and easy going, this is for you!

pros: Learned a lot and was able to keep moving up ; my executive director taught me a lot; was involved in all aspects
cons: Can feel very overwhelmed when volunteers cancel last minute, sometimes during peak season you can work a lot of hours

pros: Hard working, dedicated team with passion for the mission to end breast cancer.  Very comfortable working environment. At times very fast pace, working individually and as a team to get things done.
cons: I honestly have nothing negative to say.

pros: Great non-profit. Loved being involved in such a wonderful committee and seeing the "fruits of our labor" during Breast Cancer Awareness month in October. So much meaning behind this race. Hard to not get emotional about it.
cons: I have nothing bad to say.

job_title: Public Affairs Intern in Columbia, MO
pros: Good place to enhance the nonprofit management skills. Nice boss and effectively work environment.
cons: They don't have many people in Columbia, MO. The career opportunities are not very many. It's better to expand the company with more people and more money.

pros: Great cause, dedicated staff, so dergul mission statement
cons: Area I'm in is very clique-ish. Play favorites. All seem to belong to one particular church group. Not open to new ideas no matter what they say. Same people rewarded over and over.

pros:
Good atmosphere and camaraderie 
Nice colleagues. Very family oriented with good benefits. Working hours also good compared to other similar places
cons: Bad management and leadership. Bureaucratic red tape is real and nothing gets done until approved by the top echelon. Promotions rare

pros:
Others reported flexible schedules
Good benefits 
7.5 Hour Workday
cons: The organization has a huge goal, and for good reason, but I don't feel they built internal feasibility into that goal. They are growing too fast, and the employees feel the pain of that.

pros: I feel like I can contribute as an intern; everyone is so nice and shares the same goals; incredibly mission-driven office environment which I love!
cons: Internships aren't paid --though this is understandable because it is a nonprofit

pros: Relaxed work environment, very rewarding career & great group of volunteers to work with
cons: Poor organizational skills, documentation, and database systems

pros: The mission is true to the hearts of supporters at the local level.
cons: The National level has high turnover, no real leadership or answers for any decisions made from the top down.

pros: Great working environment within Affiliate
cons: Difficulty working between Headquarters and Affiliates; In need of innovation; No Benefits provided; Little work/life balance at times.

pros: Great cause, great global leadership
cons: Small minded board members

pros: Big organization, great outreach events in the us but limited programs internationally
cons: I worked very hard  and they always try to get the most out of you. There is preferences for some people those close to Nancy

pros: Great mission and great on a resume
cons: Management is not doing what it takes to reward those that work hard and are more likely to hire a VP than paying their workers what they should

review_title: I  have been working at panzer solutions Full-Time(Less then a year)
pros: Great place to work in panzer solutions,good learning,flexible timing,good staff supporting.i am be a part of panzer solutions.
cons: Nothing in my mind till now

review_title: A lot of flexibility and room to grow
pros: Pros was that it was small company and had a lot of hands on opportunities.
cons: No cons for this company. Very flexible with your schedule.

review_title: No corporate oversight... entire company is heading downhill.  Not trustworthy.
pros: Clients are amazing and truly appreciate the help they are given
cons: Run by people who are not professional.  Can not be trusted.  Corporate does not do what they say and there is no oversight from corporate to the affiliate.  Least professional nonprofit I have ever been a part of.

pros: Very inspiring company with a great mission in theory.
cons: Jobs are not stable as they are contingent upon the income that comes in for each affiliate.

pros: Many talented individuals passionate able the mission.
cons: Mass layoffs due to financial impact of COVID19 -  only to then go on a mass hiring spree?

job_title: Senior Director, Digital Communications Strategy in New York, NY
pros: All members of the team contribute and are recognized for their contribution.
cons: Biggest con at the moment is that the affiliate is being consolidated into the national organization.

pros: Great environment with great people, felt like a whole office of mentors
cons: Unpaid, but this is to be expected in non-profit

pros: Working for a company that does a lot of good for people that need it.
cons: Communication is non existent sometimes that can lead to difficulties in productivity

pros: Opportunities to do a lot of new things, regardless of experience
cons: Culture, equitable compensation, poor financial managemen, lack of transparency

job_title: Director of Development and Operations in Seattle, WA
pros: Working at Komen Puget Sound provided a meaningful mission, collaborative and talented team, and competitive salaries.
cons: Sometime difficult to overcome negative public image.

review_title: Resistant to change, but overall a great environment
pros: Pay interns, easy to move up, great environment, friendly people
cons: Not open to fresh ideas, salary is not great

pros: you feel a real sense of ownership over your program
cons: lack of fundamental processes to provide efficiencies and and integrated team environment. in turn, the culture suffers.

pros: My manager and coworkers are friendly and the office is small.
cons: A lot of work for a little pay. Not enough Sick/Leave time.

pros: Great mission, solid impact numbers, great research portfolio
cons: Haven’t been able to adapt to change, used to have global reach,

pros: Great benefits, amazing staff, purposful work
cons: Little opportunity for advancement due to small size of staff

pros: flexible becuse i can take days off
cons: no cons but sometimes hours can be long

job_title: Senior Affiliate Grants Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros: Flexible schedule and great location
cons: No opportunities for career growth and or development

pros: good overall experience to learn about breast cancer and fundraising
cons: would prefer not to say thanks

pros: Helping your community and making a difference
cons: Pay is low, lots of weekend and evening work

pros: Komen's strength is the staff.  The general employee population are hard-working, passionate and intelligent people who give their best every day for a great cause.
cons: Executive leadership lacks integrity and the selfless drive to effectively move the mission forward.

pros: Great Place to work, I loved being a part of a good cause
cons: it is an unpaid internship

pros: Great events, great volunteers, great team
cons: Could have had better leadership from ED

pros: passion for the cause, extensive partner relations, diligence for funding mission related activities
cons: bureaucratic, risk adverse, short term focus

pros: Overall, my manager is great. I get to network with a lot of different stakeholders.
cons: Pay, Benefits, No room for growth

pros: Great organization, they keep you up to date on the science and research aspects
cons: Internship had no compensation

pros: small close knit group in the office
cons: For me personally, there was no windows for advancement

job_title: I Like IT in Anniston, AL
pros: Good atmosphere and nice ppl to work with
cons: No hours , they are hard to get

pros: Cause, field staff, brand, flexible work hours, pto benefit
cons: Leadership, vision, lack of fundraising, reputation, infrastructure

pros: Staff, customers and work ethic were great
cons: Low pay and little room for growth

pros: See every participant cross the start line
cons: Very early hours, can be very cold!

pros: Gain hands-on experience with all facets of the organization
cons: Disconnect between management and employees

pros: very good company to work with
cons: none of the cons here

review_title: Great mission but lack of leadership
pros: Great mission and flexible work schedule
cons: lack of resources, leadership and career opportunities

pros: Lots of resources and help
cons: Less money contributed goes to actual cure for breast cancer.

job_title: Social Media Intern in Cave Creek, AZ
pros: Loved every part of working for this organization.
cons: Nothing could have been wrong.

pros: Great mission, dedicated staff.  Loved the interaction with the affiliates.
cons: Board is living in the 1990s, pre-Planned Parenthood fiasco.  Most toxic employees are often promoted, not dismissed.

pros: good money and easy travel

pros: Great mission, good work life balance

pros: awesome work environment and great staff mini

pros: Boise Idaho Affiliate has no pros
